Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The effect of rural-urban mobility on livelihood strategies and governance of conservation areas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award addresses the question: What role can be played by smallholder farmers in conservation efforts, given current global trends of rural livelihood diversification and rapid urbanization? The question is important because while many smallholder farmers live in areas significant for conservation, they also often suffer from high levels of poverty, which may lead them to shift away from strictly agricultural-based modes of living. Environmentally sustainable efforts to increase good land stewardship and governance of protected territories over generations may thus be confounded by increased circulation between rural-urban spaces and changing expectations and desires. Understanding the effects of urbanization and inter-generational changes at the local scale is crucial for broader discussions on the role of smallholder farming in protected areas in our nation's future.

To investigate these issues, Indiana University anthropology graduate student Lucy Miller, who is supervised by Dr. Eduardo S. Brondizio, will travel the Gurupá-Melgaço extractive reserve, a protected area of the Brazilian Amazon. She has chosen this region because it is home to extensive protected areas as well as to many impoverished smallholder farmers. This combination makes the conflicts between the two more apparent and easier to study than they would be in a more developed context. The global trends of rapid urbanization and processes of rural livelihood diversification are reflected in increasing reliance on cash income from public sector jobs and government welfare programs in urban centers. In this context, the researchers will investigate what impact rural-urban mobility has on livelihood strategies, resource governance across generations, and rural identity formation. The researcher will gather data through a combination of social scientific methods, including semi-structured and in-depth interviews, documentation of the types of rules and social norms in three of the reserve's communities, and household interviews in each community to ascertain intra-community variation and the role of mobility in collective action, rule compliance, contestation, and conflicts. Analysis of this information will allow the investigators to assess how rapid social change affects reserve residents' relationships with each other and their environment, and what implications these evolving relationships have for collective resource governance. Findings from the research will be of use to policymakers in the United States who are concerned with improving rural livelihoods while also promoting environmental conservation. The data will also contribute to improved social science inter-scalar theory dealing with the relationship between meso-scale collective governance and local-level household subsistence strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this award addresses the question: What role can be played by smallholder farmers in conservation efforts, given current global trends of rural livelihood diversification and rapid urbanization? The question is important because while protected areas represent the most successful strategy to reduce deforestation and implement climate change mitigation efforts in tropical regions, smallholder farmers and forest producers living in protected areas across the globe face new challenges and opportunities. Many communities have benefited from securing land and governance rights; however, they suffer from high levels of poverty amid rapid urbanization, market integration and rural livelihood diversification.

The research was conducted in the Brazilian Amazon, a region that is not only emblematic for the environmental importance of its expansive tropical rainforest but also for the vast network of protected and indigenous areas that today represents 44% of the territory. Global trends of rapid urbanization and processes of rural livelihood diversification are reflected in the region with increased reliance on cash income from public sector jobs and government welfare programs as well as greater mobility as people circulate between rural and urban areas with more facility. There is concern over generational transitions in livelihood desires as the youth disengage from agriculture and agroforestry production and potentially from the governance of protected areas. In addition, researchers are seeing more permanent youth out-migration from rural areas. Environmentally sustainable efforts to increase good land stewardship and governance of protected territories over generations may thus be confounded by increased circulation between rural-urban spaces and changing expectations and desires.

To better understand these issues, Indiana University anthropology graduate student Lucy Miller (co-PI) who is supervised by Dr. Eduardo Brondizio (PI) spent over a year living in communities located in the Amazon Estuary of Brazil. The goal was to understand the impact of rural-urban mobility on resource governance and livelihood strategies across generations of resource users residing in the Gurupá-Melgaço extractive reserve in the state of Para.

During her fieldwork, Miller gathered data using a combination of social scientific methods. Miller conducted semi-structured and in-depth interviews to examine variation in rural-urban mobility as well as the impact of mobility on rural identity formation and livelihood preferences. Using an Institutional Analysis and Development (IAD) framework, Miller documented the types of rules and social norms in three of the reserve’s communities. In addition, household interviews were conducted in each community to ascertain intra-community variation and the role of mobility in collective action, rule compliance, contestation and conflicts.

Miller competed all data collection for this project and is currently working on data analysis and producing a dissertation. The dissertation will address the following questions:  1) How do rural-urban mobility and livelihood activities vary across age and gender?  2) What are the impacts of rural-urban mobility on reserve residents’ relationships to natural resources, rural identity and livelihood choices? 3) How does variation in livelihood strategies and residency patterns affect the formation and reformulation of rules and norms around natural resource management in extractive reserves communities?

This project examines the broader potential of protected areas to meet conservation needs as well as the needs and desires of small-scale farmers amid major global trends of urbanization and rural livelihood diversification. Findings from the research have practical applications for local, national and global organizations and policy makers focusing on issues of conservation, livelihood security, and rural development. They are of use to policymakers in the United States who are concerned with improving rural livelihoods while also promoting environmental conservation.

 The data also contribute to improved social science inter-scalar theory dealing with the relationship between meso-scale collective governance and local-level household subsistence strategies. This work combines different ethnographic tools to further integrate institutional analysis and socio-demographic methods. Furthermore, the project is significant to protected areas impact evaluation by using an extensively developed analytic framework to examine not only the institutional design of the reserve but the mechanisms through which rules and norms are understood and implemented at multiple levels of analysis.
